Award.AwardTitle: TC: Small: Real-Time Intrusion Detection for VoIP over IEEE 802.11 Based Wireless Networks: An Analytical Approach for Guaranteed Performance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Voice over IP (VoIP) over IEEE 802.11 based wireless networks leads to a promising all-IP platform provisioning economic high-quality voice services to mobile users anytime and anywhere. Due to the openness and distributed nature of the protocols involved in the VoIP over wireless, it becomes easy for malicious users to achieve their own gain or disrupt the service by deviating from the normal protocol behaviors. This project develops a real-time intrusion detection framework, requiring no modification to the relevant standard protocols. Analytical tools are also developed for guiding the detection system design for guaranteed performance.

This research is expected to significantly advance the state of the art of real-time intrusion detection for VoIP over 802.11 based wireless networks, through three complementary tracks: selfish behavior detection over the 802.11 protocol, session initiation protocol (SIP)-layer attacks and detections, and development of a cross-layer intrusion detection framework. On the education front, the proposed interdisciplinary research seamlessly integrates theoretical studies in the areas of Markov decision process, wavelet analysis, 802.11 protocol analysis, and traffic modeling, as well as computer simulation and testbed experiments, with the advantages of providing various training projects to undergraduate and graduate students with different interests. On the industry front, the success of this project will generate an intrusion detection framework for the VoIP over wireless networks with the advantages of robust detection performance, provable detection quality of service, and excellent extendibility for future intrusion detection techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Voice over IP (VoIP) over IEEE 802.11 based wireless networks has emerged as a prevailing application in recent years. Due to the openness and distributed nature of the protocols involved in the VoIP over wireless, such as the session initiation protocol (SIP) and IEEE 802.11 standard, it becomes easy for malicious users in the network to achieve their own gain or disrupt the service by deviating from the normal protocol behaviors. This project has achieved a real-time intrusion detection framework that can quickly track down the malicious behaviors, without requiring modification to the relevant standard protocols. The research in this project has significantly advanced the state of the art of intrusion detection for VoIP over 802.11 based wireless networks, with contributions of a set of new tools and methodologies in three main aspects.

1) An original detector, the fair share (FS) detector, has been developed for misbehavior detection in 802.11 based networks. The FS detector has robust performance under varying network size, with either saturated or non-saturated traffic, against the short-term unfairness, and in the situation when both UDP and TCP traf?c exist. The FS detector has also been extended to multi-hop 802.11 based networks with service differentiation.

 2) Markov chain and Markov decision process based models have been developed to mathematically analyze the proposed FS detector which is in essence based on the non-parametric cumulative sum (CUSUM) test. Such a Markov-chain based model, for the first time, enables the capability of quantitative analysis of the CUSUM detector and system configuration for guaranteed detection performance.

 3) A novel sketch-based framework has been developed for detecting SIP flooding attacks. The sketch has significant advantages in easily establishing a probability model for any SIP attribute of interest, decoupled from the correlation among multiple SIP attributes. The basic sketch design has been enhanced with an original sketch distribution key (SD-key) technique to address the severe distributed denial of service (DDoS) scenario. The sketch can set a target probability distribution, which is independent of the sketch hash function and kept as confidential secrets to the SIP server. When a normal user applies for the SIP service, an SD-key will be calculated to bond the hash output together with the confidential sketch distribution.

The outcomes from this project have cross-disciplinary impact. The Markov chain based analytical models developed in this project can be applied to any CUSUM detector, which is known to be the quickest detector for identifying the change of a stochastic behavior without a priori knowledge. The Markovian model can be used to quantitatively study three fundamental metrics --- average false positive rate, average detection delay, and missed detection ratio. The Markovian model of the CUSUM detector contributes an important tool to the field of detection theory. The sketch-based model offers an important tool for applying signal processing techniques to network behavior analysis. The sketch technique can establish ?xed-size summaries of the traf?c, on which the signal processing tools can be applied for behavior analysis. The SD-key technique is also a general sketch based technique independent of specific application scenarios.

 The outcomes from this project have been published in top-tier conference proceedings and journals, and have been leveraged to enhance graduate courses and design undergraduate research projects. This project has trained highly qualified researchers and engineers for the networking and communications industry, and produced excellent PhD graduates with creativity, dedication, and professionalism.
